subject: Re: Test naming conventions (was Re: [junit] Unit Testing question)
msgSnippet: ... It has custom setup and teardown (I overrode runBare() to call those before/after JUnit s setUp()/tearDown()), and it uses them to open/close the unit doc
messageBody:
jason r tibbetts wrote:
>> Sometimes I derive all my test classes from a base test
>> class that converts the test names from CamelCase to spaces and dumps
>> them to a file - the "unit documentation".
>>
>
> I like this idea. How exactly does the base class implementation work?
>
It has custom setup and teardown (I overrode runBare() to call those
before/after JUnit's setUp()/tearDown()), and it uses them to open/close
the unit doc file.
Between the two methods, runBare() also calls a logTest() method that
writes to the file:

---begin transcript

private void logTest() {
unitDoc.println(getTestedClassName() + ":" + this.toString());
}

private String getTestedClassName() {
String testPath = this.getClass().getName();
String testName = testPath.substring(testPath.lastIndexOf('.') + 1);
return testName.substring("_Test".length());
}

public String toString() {
return super.getName().substring(4).replaceAll("([A-Z])", "
$1").toLowerCase();
}

---end transcript

You'll want to tweak this depending on your naming conventions.
> Perhaps a custom TestListener would do the
> same trick.
Good idea. I'll have to look into this. If you do this yourself, could
you please send me the code?
